newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan dollar ends at eight-year low.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan dollar ends at eight-year low.

text.p: The recently depreciating Taiwan dollar closed at an eight-year low on Friday, reflecting persistent commercial demand for the U.S. dollar, dealers said.

As it had for several days, the local unit again flirted with the central bank's T$27.9 defense level throughout the session -- trading at or below that level for hours before finishing at T$27.896 against Thursday's T$27.890 close.
Turnover through dealers was a modest US$179 million.
The Taiwan dollar has not closed lower since its T$28.03 finish on January 7, 1989.
Dealers said the central bank appeared to be unwilling to let the Taiwan dollar break psychological support at T$27.90, at least not yet.
"Just as in the past few days, the market continued to test T$27.90 but the central bank's defence was almost unbeatable," said one dealer at a foreign bank.
"The central bank understands the Taiwan dollar is in a downtrend, but it doesn't want to see the rate falls below T$27.90 immediately for some reason," the dealer said.
The Taiwan dollar struggled in a narrow circle around T$27.893 and T$27.908 throughout the day.
"The slowly depreciating trend won't change in the near term," the dealer said.

The central bank defended the dollar at T$27.5 through the 1990s but said in mid-1996 it was abandoning the policy, hinting a depreciation was welcome in the interest of stronger exports to help accelerate a stubbornly sluggish recovery.

The Taiwan dollar has been on a long, slow decline since mid-January and recently has repeatedly flirted with T$27.9, prompting dealers to predict it would break support at T$28 in the second half -- but not until the central bank is ready.
Dealers said the local market would be watching the U.S. dollar's movement in major overseas centres following the announcement of key U.S. job data at 1230 GMT on Friday.
Depending on the outcome, a narrow trading range of T$27.88-92 was seen for Saturday.
